Hi Ian,

Interesting post. I Just have a couple of points/thoughts...


>	  "Theorum #1" -- a single species that is making progress (becoming 
>fitter) at some reasonable rate, needs no extra-species interaction 
>(splitting, merging or cross-breeding).
>  
>
Hmm maybe, but. If it is fitter it will take up a larger proportion of 
the population, some poor niche species will die out and the dominant 
species will be split to bring the # of species back to normal. That 
latter speciation is therefore based upon smaller differences between 
genomes within the dominant species (This is all assuming fitness 
sharing and a dynamic compatibility threshold of course). This all means 
that your species may actually be quite compatible, compatible enough 
that interspecies mating is beneficial.

Hmm which makes me wonder if interspecies reproduction should be 
increased between more similar species, which sort of ties in with the 
next bit...

>	And "Theorum #2" -- that the only purpose of a second (or more) 
>species, is if it (i) replaces, or (ii) contributes genetic 
>information to the mainstream.
>  
>


Traditionally we tend to think of just (i), but (ii) may be happening I 
suppose. Or could be made more likely to occur. [Side though] tracking 
the history of mutations and reproductions migth be a good way of 
identifying what dynamics are actually driving progress. In a past 
project I store what the very last operation was on a genome (was it the 
product of weight mutation, add node, crossover, etc) along with it's 
parent(s) fitnesses. This means that when you evaluate, if the fitenss 
is better than your parent(s) then you can increment a counter based on 
teh type of genetic operator that was used to create the genome. So as a 
search progresses you can look at ths stats and say - of x many 
mutations y% were good, and crossover was no use... etc.

Yes I know, it's come up before and maybe you could use these stats to 
alter the search parameters. I'll get my coat shall I.


>	((Obviously it can try to do that, fail and be made extinct, but its 
>objective must be to do one of those two.))
>
>	OK, so types of speciation:
>[...]
>
>--
>
>Bottleneck Speciation
>  
>

Points noted, also refer back to 'extinct event' discussion.

>
>Side-step Speciation
>
>--
>
>Try-again Speciation
>  
>

I think of both of these as ways of doing a sort of wide or splatter 
search of the fitness space in the area around a genome/species. The 
side shift looks at the area a bit further than normal mutation, and 
try-again actually takes some large leaps out in all directions. At this 
point I'd like to re-raise my idea of ring-fencing areas of the fitness 
space as off limits, thus preventing individuals from regrouping around 
a local maxima (*). If it is a big maxima then they may form smaller 
groups around the edge of the mountain side ring fence (or think of 
volcano shape if of you prefer). This hopefully has the long term effect 
of causing more search space to be covered, away from tried and 
tested(failed) areas of the search space. But the space is approached 
more slowly than side-step, and probably even try-again.

    (*) I recently discovered that this general approach is in fact 
called a Tabu Search - which is a phrase I'd heard/read but I didn't 
know what is was. (see wikipedia!)





>
>	[[I am also interested in using "type zero" as the form of parallel 
>processing that I think I mentioned late last year, where you branch 
>the population into N copies with different random number seeds (e.g. 
>on remote machines) and after M generations select the fittest 
>version and discard the others.]]
>  
>
I currently have a discussion going off-list about distributed 
processing. I'll try and coax it onto the group. My preference is for an 
'island' model, rather than a centrally controlled 'star' model. Island 
seems  simpler and more scalable, in fact it can be made to be 
infinitely scalable.


Colin.
